title full: Camilla: or, a picture of youth. By the author of Evelina and Cecilia. In five volumes. Vol. I.
pub: ['Payne, T. and T. Cadell', 'Cadell and Davies', 'Thomas Payne', 'Thomas Cadell', 'Davies, William']
pub transcribed: Printed for T. Payne, at the Mews-Gate; and T. Cadell Jun. and W. Davies (successors to Mr. Cadell) in the Strand.
pub cataloger notes: ['Bookplate. Located on the frontispiece of all five volumes. "Cervus lacessitus leo." Inscribed by Richard Brinsley Sheridan.']
para:dedication: First line reads: "Madam, That goodness inspires a confidence, which, by divesting respect of terror, excites attachment to greatness, the presentation of this little work to Your Majesty must truly, however humbly, evince; and though a public manifestation of duty and regard from an obscure individual may betray a proud ambition, it is, I trust, but a venial -- I am sure it is a natural one."
para:advertisement: Alludes to success of Evelina and Cecilia ("The author of this little work cannot [...] refuse herself the indulgence of expressing some portion of the gratitude with which she is filled, by the highly favourable reception given to her two former attempts in this species of composition [...]") before thanking "the Hon. Mrs. Boscawen, Mrs. Crewe, and Mrs. Locke", whose "kind zeal has forwarded the present undertaking [...]"
para:footnotes: On p. 354 of Vol. III and p. 312 and 482 in Vol. V, footnotes attribute quoted lines of text to Dryden, Shakespeare and Young.

author transcribed: published by the author of David Simple : in two volumes.
title catalog: The history of Ophelia / published by the author of David Simple : in two volumes.
title full: The history of Ophelia. Published by the author of David Simple. In two volumes. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for R. Baldwin, at the Rose, in Pater-Noster-Row
pub cataloger notes: ['The Author of David Simple is Sarah Fielding.  Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.)']
para:advertisement: First lines: "I am obliged to fortune, for the papers I now offer to the publick. I little imagined, when I bought an old buroe, that I was purchasing a work of fancy; for such I must suspect this little work to be, though it contains many incidents that bear so much the appearance of reality, that they might claim some share of our belief."
para:intro: Written in the first person, the introduction is signed by Ophelia, and addresses "Your Ladyship," who evidently compelled the fictional character to write her account: "Your Ladyship had little compassion either on yourself or me, when you desired me to write you an exact account of every circumstance of my life, and even of my thoughts, or you did not consider the long detail into which this lead me [...] You expressly desire to know the impressions I recieved from the first view of customs so unlike what I had ever seen, at a time when they are become so familiar to me, that I almost forgot many of them were ever otherwise."

para:advertisement: The publisher of this volume is under some difficulties; not from any apprehensions of losing by the book; for great part of the impression is bespoke; his anxiety arises from the author's addressing the volume to him, and making him a compliment in the beginning; which, as he is conscious he does not deserve, he hopes the reader will impute to its proper cause, namely, to the warmth of friendship, which is too apt to exhalt the object it esteems. [...]

para:footnotes: Some footnotes  explain historical or legal concepts as well as provide certian definitions. The majority, however, are translations of Greek or Latin text.

para:preface: First lines read: "In sending into the world a work so unlike those of my former writings, which have been honored by its approbation, I feel some degree of that apprehension which an author is sensible of on a first draft of publication. This arises partly from my doubts of succeeding so well in letters as in narrative; and partly from a supposition, that there are readers, to whom the fictitious occurences, and others to whom the political remarks in these volumes may be displeasing."

title half: Adventures of Caleb Williams.
pub: ['G.G. and J. Robinson', 'Robinson, George', 'Robinson, George', 'Robinson, John']
pub transcribed: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row.
pub cataloger notes: ['Bookplate. Located on the front pastedown of every volume. Reads "Library University of Pennsylvania; Bibliotheca Universitatis Pennsylvaniensis; Rittenhouse Orrery; Henry H. Bonnell Collection."']
para:preface: First lines read: "The following narrative is intended to answer a purpose more general and important than immediately appears on the face of it. The question now afloat in the world respecting things as they are, is the most interesting that can be presented to the human mind. While one party pleads for reformation and change, the other extols in the warmest terms the existing constitution of society."
para:footnotes: Footnotes on p. 208 and 210 appear in volume two after the descriptions of events in the text; they confirm the validity of the circumstances described. The first reads: "An incident exactly similar to this, was witnessed by a friend of the author, a few years since, in Newgate." The second reads: "A story extremely similar to this can be found in the Newgate Calendar, Vol. I p. 282."

author transcribed: Tr. from the French, by W. Hooper, M. A.
title catalog: Memoirs of the year two thousand five hundred ... Tr. from the French, by W. Hooper, M. A.
title full: Memoirs of the year two thousand five hundred. Translated from the French, by W. Hooper, M.A.
pub transcribed: Printed by Thomas Dobson, at the Stone-House, N° 41, South Second-Street
pub cataloger notes: ["Translation of: L'an deux mille quatre cent quarante."]
para:dedication: Transcription of the opening sentences: "August and venerable year! thou who art to bring felicity upon the earth! thou, alas! that I have only in a dream behled, when thou shalt rise from out the bosom of eternity, thy sun shall enlighten them who will tread upon my ashes, and upon those of thirty generations, successively cut off, and plunged in the profound abyss of death."
para:advertisement: This paratextual essay purports to describe the translation choices, including rounding the original title - "The year two thousand four hundred and forty" - and changing "the names of places and persons, to almost all the capital cities of Europe." (ii).
para:intro: The introduction begins: "That all should be well is the wish of the philsopher [...] Why may not the human race resembe an individual? Touchy, hasty, thoughtless, in youth; gentle, patient, prudent in age*. The man who argues thus imposes on himself the duty of being just [...] For me, concentered with Pato, I dream like him."

title catalog: The democrat; or Intrigues and adventures of Jean le Noir, : from his inlistment as a drummer in General Rochembeau\\\'s army, and arrival in Boston, to his being driven from England in 1795, after having borne a conspicuous part in the French Revolution, and after a great variety of enterprizes, hazards and escapes during his stay in England, where he was sent in quality of democratic missionary. : In two volumes. title full: The democrat; or intrigues and adventures of Jean le Noir, from his inlistment as a drummer in General Rochembeau's army, and arrival at Boston, to his being driven from England in 1795, after having borne a conspicous part in the French Revolution, and after a great variety of enterprizes, hazards, and escapes during his stay in England, where he was sent in quality of democratic missionary. In two volumes. Vol. I
title half: The democrat
pub transcribed: Printed for James Rivington, no. 156 Pearl-Street.,
pub cataloger notes: ['Attributed to Pye in the Dictionary of national biography.']
para:preface: The opening setences read: "In the following work the public are presented with the life and adventures of a democratic missionary, sent from the metropolitan see of sedition and murder at Paris, to progate their principles in a neighboring country. The reception he met with among the different orders of the people, and his awkaward, though zealous endeavours in the cause of liberty and equality, will not fail of yielding the reader an abundance of amusment: but these adventures, besides being in themselves sufficiently diverting, have an additional claim to the attention of the american reader at this moment, when circumstances render them applicable to ourselves."
para:footnotes: Foonotes appear in Vol. I on pages 18, 22, 71, and 128; and in Vol. II on pages 3, 11, 18, 37, 129, 155, 156.

title catalog: The adventures of Mr. George Edwards, a creole.
title full: The adventures of Mr. George Edwards, a creole.  The second edition.

pub transcribed: Printed for T. Osborne, in Gray\\\'s-Inn.
pub cataloger notes: ["Publisher's advertisements: p. [1]-[3] at the end."]
para:preface: Excerpt from the preface: "It has been too much a custom among the modern writers of romance, to expose persons instead of vices or follies; and to draw from real life, the characters of a work, the very plan and intent of which bespeaks it fiction [...] It is with great seriousness, that the writer of these adventures declares, that there is in the world, no such persons as the hero of them, or as any other character described in them: The persons are all, so far at least, Tom jones's and Clarissa's [...]"

author transcribed: translated from the Swedish ; to which are prefixed those of Her present Majesty to her son.
title catalog: Letters from an old man to a young prince : with the answers / translated from the Swedish ; to which are prefixed those of Her present Majesty to her son.
title full: Letters from an old man to a young prince; with the answers.  Translated from the Swedish.  To which are prefixed those of Her present Majesty to her son.  Vol. I.  The second edition.
pub transcribed: Printed for R. Griffiths, in Pater-noster-Row.
pub cataloger notes: ['Translation of: Gammal mans bref til en ung prints.']
para:preface: First line reads: "Since neither Mr. Maupertuis's Latin Town, nor any other scheme of universal language, is likely to take, either for want of proper encouragement, or from some natural difficulty in the thing itself; we must content ourselves with translations instead of originals, with secondary dimness in the room of primary lustre. [...]"
para:dedication: Sir, I should have more fear, and less inclination, to lay these letters at the feet of Your Royal Highness, if I had been the original author of them; but they were wrote by so great, so sensible, and so honest a man, to a young Prince who, in the common course of things, will, one day, be a contemporary king with Your Royal Highness, that I cannot help thinking them worth your reading. [...]
para:to the reader: First lines read: "Gentle reader!  Whether thou art a wise man or the contrary; sitting in thy study, sauntering in the field, or lounging in a bookseller's shop [...]: I must desire thee to hear me, the publisher, before thou proceedest."
para:footnotes: Footnotes can be found in Vol. I on pages 86, 184, and 225; in Vol. II on pages 33, 42, 167, 169, 171, 181, 198, 200-2, 205-6, and 226; and in Vol. III on pages 41, 45, 60, 73, 138-9, 141-2, and 145.

para:preface: Begins with a character sketch of the Chevalier de Mainvillers, who "was the delight of the gay, the young and the fair" and "had the advantage of a double experience [...] in the double capacity of a man of letters, and the fine gentleman." The author of the preface notes that "his faults and vices are very numerous" and advises "none therefore [...] pretend to imitate him in his guilty pleasures." The editor then addresses the reader, apologizing for "frequently fail[ing] in translating the sallies of our author's wit" and giving an account of the difficulties of translation. A description of the success of the French edition, and excerpts from a review published in The Novelle Litteraires of France, are also included.
para:to the reader: The note is marked by three asterisks, and is found on the verso of the page facing the full title. It reads: "The public may be assured that this work is not a romance, but the genuine memoirs of a person now residing in London, and very well known to the polite world."
para:footnotes: Footnotes that describe the external world appear on pages 28, 31, 36, 49, 61, 65, 109, 113, 120, and 188.

pub transcribed: Printed by George Faulkner; in Essex-street.
pub notes: The History of Pompey
pub cataloger notes: ['Bound with "Letters written by a Peruvian Princess.  Translated from the French."']
para:advertisement: Begins: "If truth, when it strays from probability, usually loses its credit in the eye of reason, it is for a short time only; but, let it contradict prejudice ever so little, and seldom shall it find grace before that tribunal. What then ought not the editor of this work to fear, in presenting to the public the letters of a young Peruvian, whose stile and thoughts so little agree with the mean idea which an unjust prejudice has caused us to form of her nation? Enriched by the precious spoils of Peru, we ought, at least, to regard the inhabitants of that part of the world as a magnificent people; and the sentiment of respect is not very remote from the idea of magnificence. But so prejudiced are we always in our own favour, that we rate the merit of other nations not only in proportion as their manners imitate ours, but in proportion as their tongues approach nearer to our Idiom. How can one be a Persian? We despite the Indians, and hardly grant a thinking soul to those unhappy people: yet their history is in every one's hands, and abounds with monuments of the sagacity of their minds, and the solidity of their philosophy. The apologist of humanity and of beautiful nature has traced the out-lines of the Indian manners in a dramatic poem, the subject of which divides the glory with the execution.With so much light given us into the characters of these people, there should seem no room to fear that original letters which only exhibit what we already know of the lively and natural wit of the Indians, are in danger of passing for a fiction. But, that prejudice any eyes? There is no fecundity against its judgement, and we should have been careful not to submit this work to it, if its empire has been without bounds. It seems needless to give notice, that the first letters of Zilia were translated by herself: every one must easily judge, that, being composed in a language, and traced in a manner equally unknown to us, this collection could never have reached us, if the same hand had not writ them in our tongue. We owe this translation to Zilia's leisure in her retreat: her complaisance in communicating them to the chevalier Deterville, and the permission he at last obtained to keep them, were the means that conveyed them into our hands."
para:footnotes: In reference to the question "How can one be a Persian?"

para:preface: Begins: "It is a pretty general curiousity before one enters on the reading a book, to be inquisitive about who is its author, and with what intent it was written [...]". The author of the preface claims that this book "was written for the service of a daughter", and that the "vice" which appears in the title character is "to the rational mind the most striking of all lessons of morality," and therefore "permitted."
para:footnotes: A footnote appears on p. 8-9 commenting on the origin of the phrase "rosy neck." An editorial remark occurs at the note's conclusion: "If thou shouldst be unlucky enough to ask, gentle reader, to what purpose serves this note? we shall answer thee in the sarcastic way, by asking thee, To what end serve all other notes but to shew the author's reading?"

para:preface: Transcription of the opening lines: "Besides the prefaces already affix'd to each single volume of these letters, which contain particular answers to the objections and cavills of some, with solutions of the scruples and doubts made by others; as likewise critical explanations of passages, seeming obscure to all, in the English tranaslation of our spy: it is thought necessary to prefix something more by way of a general prefce, not so much regarding the translation as the seeming original abruptness and obscurity of our Arabian author himself in some places, with his frequent change of subjects, his digressions and startings from matter of fact, the then present wards, transactions, and intrigues of Christian courts, states, and kingdoms (for which he was chiefly sent to Paris) and his immethodical falling upon philosophical, divine, and moral contemplations, and even to ancient, obsolete histories, which some think were altogether foreign to his business."
para:to the reader: Describes the finding of the book by "a man of letters" who "discovered by mere chance in the corner of his chamber a great heap of papers". Goes on to describe some of the contents of the work, as well as the process of translating it.

title catalog: The hermit, or, The unparalleled sufferings, and surprizing adventures, of Philip Quarll, an Englishman, who was discovered by Mr. Dorrington, a Bristol merchant, upon an uninhabited island, in the South-sea, where he lived above fifty years, without any human assistance. ... : with a curious frontispiece.
title full: The hermit: Or, the unparalleled sufferings and surprizing adventures, of Philip Quarll, an Englishman: Who was discovered by Mr. Dorrington, a Bristol merchant, upon an uninhabited island, in the South-sea; where he lived above fifty years, without any human assistance. Containing I. His Conference with those who found him out; to whom he recites the most material circumstances of his life; as, that he was born in the parish of St. Giles, educated by the charitable contribution of a lady, and put 'prentice to a locksmith. II. How he left his master, and took up with a notorious house-breaker, who was hanged; how, after his escape, he went to sea a cabin-boy, married a famous whore, listed himself a common soldier, turned a singing-master, and married three wives, for which he was tried and condemned, at the Baily. III. How he was pardoned by K. Charles II. turned merchant, and was shipwrecked on a desolate island on the coast of Mexico. With a curious frontispiece.
pub transcribed: Printed for the book-sellers.

para:preface: First line transcription: "An early foundation for Virtue is, beyond all contradiction, a duty incumbent both on the parent and guardian; whose chief aim should be to sew those seeds which length of time cannot eradicate; and the most effectual way is that of painting virtue arrayed in all her beauties, and vice as she really is--hateful; at the same time shewing the pleasures which result from the former, and the various ills which are the constant attendants on the latter."

para:dedication: Transcription: "Madam, Anxious for the Success of the following Work, I wished to introduce it to the World under the Auspices of Mrs. Pitt, convinced that her Suffrage would ever do it Honour."
para:intro: Transcription: "In the summer of 17**, two gentlemen, well known in the literary world, made an excursion into Wales, not merely to view the country and those monuments of Druidical superstition which have been so frequently examined and described, but to visit the villages in the neighborhood of every place which is supposed to have been a seat of the Druids, and where they thought it probable the peasants might retain many traditions and customs which would throw light upon the imperfect account transmitted to us of their religious rites and ceremonies, and explain some points in the history of those early ages, which are at present exceedingly obscure."

para:dedication: My Lord, -- Unused and averse to the language of flattery, or the cant of dedication, I present this work to you, persuaded your Lordship disdains to receive adulation as much as I do offering it; and flattering myself you will not, though a nice judge of writing, view it with the eye of criticism--but with indulgence pardon the errors of a first essay, and the humble offering of one who, though unknown, has the honor of being allied to you.
para:footnotes: Remains of the ancient people of Vaudois, who inhabited the vallies lying between Provence and Dauphiny in France. For an account of them see Voltaire's works.

pub cataloger notes: ['The author of The trifler is Henry Man. Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.), v. 6, p. 99.']
para:preface: Transcription of first sentence: "Looking the other day over some old Magazines, which had quietly rested untouched at the bottom of a decayed trunk for many years, I found an account given in the Critical Review for July 1777, of a work I published entitled the Trifler; and as these great and tremendous Law-givers (the whole tribe of Reviewers) preside over as judges, nay more, are absolute monarchs over literary merit, I took it into my head to avail myself of their commendations of my former Work, by announcing this performance to be written by the same Author; as also to give the reader the underneath words of the Review in question, that he might form some kind of an idea what sort of a creature this Trifler was, and what he might expect from him in the present publication."
para:footnotes: Located on page 234. Transcription:"*1789."

title catalog: The works of Laurence Sterne : complete in eight volumes.
title full: The works of Laurence Sterne. Complete in eight volumes. Containing, I. Tristram Shandy, and the political romance. II. Sentimental Journey, with the continuation. III. The Koran....IV. Letters....V. Sermons. With an account of the life and writings of the author. Volume the first.

title series: The works of Laurence Sterne. Complete in eight volumes.
pub transcribed: Printed for the proprietors.
pub cataloger notes: ['Includes an account of the life and writings of the author.']
para:preface: First sentence: "No, I'll not say another word about it---here it is; --in publishing it-- I have appealed to the world---and to the world I leave it;---it must speak for itself."
para:dedication: Transcription of first sentence: "Sir, Never poor wight of a Dedicator had less hopes from his Dedication, than I have from this of mine; for it is written in a by-corner of the kingdom, and in a retired thatch'd house, where I live in a constant endeavour to fence against the infirmities of ill health, and other evils of life, by mirth; being firmly persuaded, that every time a man smiles - but much more so when he laughs - that it adds something to this Fragment of Life.
para:advertisement: First sentence: "This little piece was written by Mr Sterne in the year 1759, but, for private reasons, was then suppressed."
para:to the reader: First sentence: "I here present the Public with the remains of an Author who has long entertained and amused them, and who has been the subject both of applause and censure-- himself equally regardless of both."
para:footnotes: p.99. Beginning: "The Romish Rituals direct the baptizing of the child, in cases of danger, before it is born;--but upon this proviso, that some part of the child's body be seen by the baptizer;--..." End: "If the reader has the curiosity to see the question upon baptism by injection, as presented to the Doctors of the Sorbonne, with their consultation thereupon, it is as follows." An account is then presented in the text in French.

"Interesting quote from p.iv: "I confess I am somewhat of a Democrat; and am more pleased with the strength of faculties, and dignity of character, that can make station refulgent, than with inert Nobility; which rolled up in itself, might be trod on in society, did not its glow-worm light give a faint warning of its reptile existence." Signed "I am, Sir, With the respect you merit, Your very humble and obliged servant, Maria Hunter."

title full: The wanderings of Warwick. By Charlotte Smith.
title half: The wanderings of Warwick.
pub transcribed: Printed for J. Bell, No. 148, Oxford-Street.
pub cataloger notes: ['Copy 1.']
para:advertisement: Transcription: "So long a period having elapsed since the speedy publication of The Wanderings of Warwick in two volumes was announced, the Publisher conceives he should be wanting in that respect which he owes to the Public, were he now silently to publish the work in one, without stating in his own exculpation, that both the delay, and the promising it in two volumes, are imputable solely to the Author--to whom he leaves the task of justifying her own conduct." Signed: "Oxford-Street, January 13, 1794."
para:footnotes: Located on pg.66-67. Transcription: "Notwithstanding my apprehensions that Novel-readers, in their eagerness for mere narrative, will murmur..."

para:advertisement: Transcription: "So long a period having elapsed since the speedy publication of The Wanderings of Warwick in two volumes was announced, the Publisher conceives he should be wanting in that respect which he owes to the Public, were he now silently to publish the work in one, without stating in his own exculpation, that both the delay, and the promising it in two volumes, are imputable solely to the Author--to whom he leaves the task of justifying her own conduct." para:footnotes: Located on pg.66. Transcription of first part: "Notwithstanding my apprehensions that Novel-readers, in their eagerness for mere narrative, will murmur at being detained by a sort of differtation on negro slavery, I should have tempted their patience for a few pages more..."

pub: ['Wogan, Patrick', 'Byrne, Patrick', 'Moore, James', 'Jones, William', 'Rice, John', 'Colbert, H. (Harriot)']
pub transcribed: Printed by Thomas Burnside, for Messrs. P. Wogan, P. Byrne, J. Moore, W. Jones, J. Rice, and H. Colbert.
pub cataloger notes: ['Reprint of the first, London, edition of 1794.']
para:preface: First sentence transcription: "Whoever has the condescension to honour these pages with a perusal, let them not toss away the inoffesive volume with disgust, because the first characters I shall introduce to their acquaintance happen to be a little lower in the scale of rank than themselves--very much lower I should have said; for I shall begin my history, when I do begin it, with a couple of God's good creatures, so simple, so natural, as makes me tremble for the reception they may meet with in their career through high life." The author also explicitly states that this chapter is intended "as a sort of preface."

para:footnotes: p. 28: "History says, 'that duke Frederic entered the wood alone, leaving his attendants at the distance of a bow-shot. Kurd, the chief of his guards, impatient at his delay, followed him and found him assassinated. He was time enough to see the murderers escape, and even came up with one of them, whose name was Hertingshausen.'"

pub transcribed: Printed for W. Strahan; and T. Cadell, in the Strand.
pub cataloger notes: ['Published anonymously. By Henry Mackenzie.']
para:to the reader: The note begins with a printed manicula. Transcription: "The Reader will remember, that the Editor is accountable only for scattered chapters, and fragments of chapters; the curate must answer for the rest. The number at the top, when the chapter was entire, he has given as it originally stood which the title with its author had affixed to it."
para:intro: Transcription of first sentence: "My dog had made a point on a piece of fallow-ground, and led the curate and me two or three hundred yards over that and some stubble adjoining, in a breathless state of expectation, on a burning first of September." Explains how the editor came into the possession of documents about the life of a man named Harley. Introduction is 6 pages long. Running title of introduction: "Introduction."

para:footnotes: Located on page 208. Transcription: "These are real extracts from a paper signed Puthod, Adjutant-General, and published as mentioned in the text. Such absurd affectation and pedantry are hardly credible. Who but a French Republican could be capable of them?"

pub transcribed: Printed for the author, and sold at his warehouse, No. 411, Strand, opposite the Adelphi.
pub notes: This book was published in 1793, but this information is not printed on the title page.
pub cataloger notes: ['Library Marginalia: Green sticker in upper left corner of front pasted endpaper reading "Rare Book Collection Library University of Pennsylvania" in volumes one, two, and three']
para:preface: The author considers the reception of several well-known writers, as well as the reception of his own work. First sentence: "There cannot be any thing so fallacious as the cavils of those authors who complain of being unjustly treated by the public." Running title: "Preface."
para:dedication: Dedicated "to the most noble the Marquis of Salisbury." First sentence: "My Lord, To neglect any proper opportunity of testifying my devotion to your Lordship, would be unjust, unworthy, and ungrateful; therefore, I only comply with the most manifest propriety in humbly soliciting your protection to this work." Signed: "I am, My Lord, Your Lordship's Greatly honoured, obliged, And obedient servant, C. Dibdin." Dated: "Strand, Jan. 8, 1793." Running title: "Dedication."

Signed "John Hawkesworth"
